page.title: 03ECOLOGY
page.content: The low lying areas are the result of an extensive drainage scheme that took place in the mid seventeenth century under the guidance of a Dutchmen, Cornelius Vermuyden. Much of the area had been excavated during the last ice age and was below sea level, once the ice age had finished the area flooded and was known as the{Fens}.The main aim of his scheme was to straighten the river courses and take the water off the land. Once this had been achieved the peaty nature of the soils meant that they shrank and so the general level of the land was lowered. Another problem resulting from this drainage scheme was that the soils were now more liable to soil erosion from the wind. The area that used to be flooded/marshy is now the very level area found either side of the River Ouse.
